title: What next for Luis Rubiales , his allies and those who applauded him last week ?
body_text:
One week ago, Luis Rubiales made his incendiary speech at the Spanish Football Federation (RFEF) headquarters near Madrid.
In a 30-minute rant, he tried to justify his crotch grab in celebration of Spainâ€™s Womenâ€™s World Cup final win, while in the VIP section of the stand just feet from his countryâ€™s queen and her young daughter, called his unsolicited kiss of the teamâ€™s forward Jenni Hermoso during the post-match presentation ceremony on the pitch a â€œconsensual peckâ€ and insisted â€œI will NOT resignâ€ five times.

Over the seven days since, world footballâ€™s governing body FIFA provisionally suspended him, Spainâ€™s prosecutorâ€™s office opened an investigation into whether he committed sexual assault and his mother went on hunger strike in her local church in protest at his treatment. And there are sure to be further developments as Rubiales and his supporters try to fight what he described in that speech as a â€œsocial assassinationâ€.
Many were shocked by the reception Rubiales was given before, during and after his speech.

Misa Rodriguez, Spainâ€™s backup goalkeeper for the 1-0 victory over England in Sydney, highlighted that when replying to a post supporting Hermoso with: â€œNot to mention all those people who applauded.â€

So who exactly were the major figures among those clapping his words, and what have they done, or said, since?
National team managers
The pictures of Spain womenâ€™s team boss Jorge Vilda and his menâ€™s game counterpart Luis de la Fuente applauding Rubialesâ€™ speech caused the most consternation. They were sitting in the front row next to Fede Vidal, manager of the countryâ€™s menâ€™s futsal team, who also clapped enthusiastically throughout.
Rubiales directly addressed Vilda several times â€” including when promising to almost triple his salary on the spot â€” and praised De La Fuente for his role in Juneâ€™s Nations League final win over Croatia.
The pair applauded when Rubiales claimed the narrative around the Hermoso kiss had been manufactured by media outlets â€œpaying tribute to (La Liga president Javier) Tebasâ€ and had been fanned by â€œfalse feminism, which is a great blot on this countryâ€.

Later on, Vilda and De la Fuente joined in the widespread clapping and continued to do so as Rubiales repeated he would not resign. They also showed their support when he directly addressed his daughters (who were sitting behind them) to tell them they were the â€œreal feminists, and not of the â€˜false feminismâ€™ thatâ€™s out thereâ€. Vilda and De la Fuente were among the first to rise in a standing ovation at the end of the speech.
After FIFA suspended Rubiales the following day, however, both men rowed back on their support.
De la Fuente released a statement that day in which he expressed his â€œabsolute repulsion in the face of any act of misogynistic violenceâ€, adding that he â€œunreservedly censured the mistaken and out of place behaviour of the RFEF presidentâ€. The manager is expected to comment further on the issue today (Friday) at a press conference to announce his latest squad for European Championship qualifiers next week against Georgia and Cyprus.
Vilda put out his own statement later, saying Rubialesâ€™ behaviour â€œabsolutely does not reflect the principles and values that I defendâ€.
Yesterday, interim RFEF president Pedro Rocha said that De la Fuenteâ€™s job was â€œtotallyâ€ safe but was more vague regarding Vildaâ€™s future after reports that the Womenâ€™s World Cup winner would be sacked.
â€œWe canâ€™t say that because we wonâ€™t meet with him until next week,â€ Rocha said. â€œOnce weâ€™ve met, obviously weâ€™ll give the relevant news.â€
Vidal, menâ€™s futsal manager since 2018, has not publicly spoken since Rubialesâ€™ speech. The Athletic has approached him for comment.
Spain womenâ€™s coaching staff
Also in the front row at RFEF headquarters a week ago were various members of the victorious womenâ€™s sideâ€™s coaching staff, newly returned from Australia. The camera regularly panned to under-19s and under-20s coach Sonia Bermudez, senior-team assistant coach Montserrat Tome, technical analyst Ruben Jimenez Gomez, goalkeeping coach Carlos Sanchez, youth goalkeepers coach Elena Fernandez Castano and physical trainer Blanca Romero (shown from left to right in the screengrab below).
They did not always respond to Rubialesâ€™ speech, with Fernandez Castano and Romero looking visibly awkward throughout. Only Sanchez applauded when he made his first reference to â€œfalse feminismâ€ â€” Bermudez and Tome stared at the RFEF president. Jimenez Gomez and Fernandez Castano looked away.
Rubiales made another unexpected announcement when he said he wanted Tome to take over from Vilda as sporting director (he holds that role as well as being manager of the senior womenâ€™s side).

Addressing the rest of the coaching staff, he said: â€œAll the team, you already know that youâ€™re going to renew and that weâ€™re going to talk and that thereâ€™s going to be an economic improvement.â€ Sanchez was the first to rise in the front row as the standing ovation began before other members of staff slowly followed.
Next day, 11 members of the womenâ€™s coaching staff released a joint statement in which they said they had been made to attend the assembly and that â€œvarious female members of the technical staff were obliged to put themselves in the first row, exposing their image and trying to suggest to society and players that they shared the RFEF presidentâ€™s thesisâ€.
They expressed their â€œmost firm and categorical condemnationâ€ of Rubialesâ€™ behaviour and said they â€œput their jobs at the disposalâ€ of the RFEF.
The statement was signed by Tome, Romero, Sanchez, Jimenez Gomez, Bermudez and Fernandez Castano â€” along with assistants Javier Lerga and Eugenio Gonzalo Martin, physical trainer Javier Velazquez Diaz, youth technical analyst Javier Egido Saz and another of the youth setupâ€™s goalkeeper coaches, Ander Ruiz Mitxelana.

RFEF directors and regional leaders
Rubiales praised the RFEF directors and regional leaders with him on stage, including a few by name.
â€œThe best of football is here,â€ he said, pointing to those sitting to his left, â€œthese people who have trusted in me to be the president of the federation for these past five years, which is the biggest gift of my life.â€
The assembly was chaired by RFEF general secretary and Rubiales ally Andreu Camps, who the president called on to negotiate with Vilda over his new deal. He also pointed out Rafa del Amo (first row, second right in the grab below), an RFEF vice-president and member of its womenâ€™s football committee, when underlining the increased investment in womenâ€™s football during his presidency.
Not everybody on stage applauded when Rubiales made his surprise announcement about plans to extend Vildaâ€™s contract and only six joined in with the standing ovation when the president returned to his seat â€” with Camps giving him a hug.
Del Amo would resign from his position after the assembly on Friday, along with four other regional federation presidents.

â€œI felt like he was stepping on me in a lot of things â€” for example, the message to Vilda or to Montse Tome,â€ Del Amo has subsequently said. â€œI was president of the national committee and he hadnâ€™t consulted me about it, like he did on many occasions at the World Cup.â€
There was a further twist when it emerged Camps sent a letter asking UEFA, European footballâ€™s governing body, to suspend the RFEF over government interference later that day â€” which would have meant Spanish clubs such as title holders Barcelona and Real Madrid being kicked out of the Champions League and the other two European competitions. He did this after the president of Spainâ€™s High Sports Council said the countryâ€™s government had initiated procedures for Rubiales to give explanations before its Administrative Court of Sport.
But UEFA decided to take no action and on Monday the presidents of Spanish footballâ€™s regional and territorial federations urged Rochas to withdraw that letter, while calling on Rubiales to â€œimmediately resignâ€ over his â€œunacceptable behavioursâ€ that â€œseriously damaged the image of Spanish footballâ€.
Could Rubiales, Camps and Vilda face further action from RFEF?
Speaking to reporters at the Champions League group-stage draw in Monaco yesterday, acting RFEF president Rocha was non-committal on the subject of what further action the federation might take against Rubiales.
â€œWe are very clear that the institution is above individuals. Unity and consensus is required,â€ he said. â€œWeâ€™re here to support our five Spanish teams (in the Champions League) because our image is very important. There is a lot in play. We have the World Cup (bid for co-hosting rights of the menâ€™s tournament in 2030) in future.
â€œIâ€™m an institution man, the presidents have all backed me, and I have a duty to the RFEF. If there is no resignation (from Rubiales), then itâ€™s just about working, working and working. Weâ€™ve navigated against the wind before, and now must do it again. Weâ€™ve made a great federation and must keep on.â€
Having already called on Rubiales to resign, the RFEFâ€™s regional presidents could next ask for a motion of censure against him, though sources close to the situation describe that as unlikely to happen any time soon.

Another option would be to elect a new permanent president quickly, by moving up elections currently scheduled for the second half of 2024. If the RFEF makes a request to the Spanish government, these could be held in the first half of next year.
The position of Vilda, who went into the World Cup unpopular among many of Spainâ€™s best female players, does appear precarious. Further to Rochaâ€™s quotes on the subject above, several regional RFEF presidents told The Athletic they expect him to be removed from his position in the coming days.
As for general secretary Camps, his fate seems unclear at the moment. It will depend on the will of RFEF members.
